titlestmt.titleproper: Georgetown, Mass. First Congregational Church records, 1731-1866.
titlestmt.author: Zachary Bodnar, Cristina Prochilo, Sari Mauro

seriesstmt.p: This collection is part of New England's Hidden Histories. Digital historical representations of the collection can be viewed online.

conventiondeclaration.citation: Describing Archives: A Content Standard, Second Edition

maintenanceevent.eventdescription: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday July 17, 2019 at 20:10
Zachary Bodnar: added digital copies notes to each individual record and removed the general digital copies note from the collection level notes field, minor revision of a subject heading.

did.unittitle: Georgetown, Mass. First Congregational Church records, 1731-1866.
did.abstract: The First Congregational Church in Georgetown was originally established in 1731 as Rowley West Parish. When the town of Georgetown was incorporated in 1838, the Rowley West Parish was renamed to the First Congregational Church of Georgetown. The collection includes meeting minutes, financial records and valuable vital records.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is unrestricted and open to the public.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Items in this collection are subject to U.S. Copyright Law. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine the copyright status of collection items and to secure any permissions necessary for their reproduction and publication. Requests for permission to publish material must be discussed with the archivist or librarian.

Digital Reproductions are protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use the Digital Reproductions in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. In addition, no permission is required from the Congregational Library & Archives for educational uses. For other uses, you need to obtain permission from the Congregational Library & Archives. For additional information regarding copyright, please consult the Congregational Library & Archives' Digital Collections Copyright & Use policy.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], in the Georgetown, Mass. First Congregational Church records, 1731-1866, RG4967. The Congregational Library & Archives, Boston, MA.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Loaned to the Congregational Library & Archives, August 2011, by the First Congregational Church in Georgetown, Mass; no accession number.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Additional accruals are expected for this collection in the form of full-text transcription. There is no anticipated date for this accrual.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Originally processed by Christina Prochilo, November 2012. Additional description by Sari Mauro, October 2013, using DACS Second Edition. Additional processing by Zachary Bodnar, August 2018, using DACS Second Edition.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The First Congregational Church in Georgetown was originally established in 1731 as the Rowley West Parish, also known as the Second Parish. Prior to the church's founding, parishioners had to travel a significant distance to worship in Rowley or neighboring Byfield. By 1768 the parish had outgrown its original meeting house and a new building was built. This meeting house, later known as Old South Church, was constructed on the corners of East Main and Elm Streets in 1769.

When the town of Georgetown was incorporated in 1838, the Rowley West Parish was renamed to the First Congregational Church of Georgetown. The third and final meeting house was constructed in 1874 along Andover Street. In 1908, the church merged with the Orthodox Memorial Church. In 1961, the church voted to become a member of the United Church of Christ. The First Congregational Church in Georgetown continues to serve the community today.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The First Congregational Church records of Georgetown, Mass. document the activities and history of the church organization and its members. The documents include meeting and committee minutes, financial records, membership records, vital records, and sermon manuscripts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has been arranged in chronological order by start date.

phystech.head: Technical Requirements
phystech.p: To access digital user's copies via online-interface, a java-enabled web browser is required. Internet Explorer 8.x and later, Firefox 5.x and later, Opera 12 and later, Safari 5.x and later, or any version of Google Chrome are recommended.

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume contains records of the officers' meetings for the West Parish in Rowley, concerning the oversight of the property and finances. It includes records of parish votes for the officers' and ministers' salaries, various committee assignments, pew subscriptions, and upkeep of the meetinghouse.

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unlike most similar records of the time, this volume records actual birth (rather than baptismal) dates, along with the names of the parents and locations of baptisms.

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume contains a list of the members and children of members who passed away. Each entry includes the date and approximate age, as well as parents for those who died young.

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online. Transcriptions of this record are also available and can be viewed alongside the digital images.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume primarily contains membership records for the Second Parish Church in Rowley. These include admissions, dismissions, baptisms, and disciplinary cases. There is also a copy of the covenant signed by the founding members.

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This shortened version of the original church covenant was likely used to admit new members. It includes references to the "Westminster Assembly's catechism" and the "sacraments of the New Testament"

did.unittitle: Sermons preached by Rev. Isaac Braman at Byfield

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These sermons were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains manuscript sermons written and preached by Rev. Isaac Braman.

list.head: List of Sermons
list.item: Proverbs 30:12 â "There is a generation that are pure in their own eyes, yet is not washed from their filthiness."
Proverbs 13:9 â "The light of the righteous rejoiceth: But the Lamp of the wicked shall be put out."
Proverbs 1:33 â "But whoso hearkeneth unto me, shall dwell safely, shall be quiet from fear of evil."
Philippians 2:9-11 â "Wherefore God hath highly exalted him, given him a name which is above every name: that at the name of Jesus every knee should bowâ¦"
Proverbs 23:17-18 â "Let not thine heart envy Sinners: but be thou in the fear of the Lord all the day long. For surely there is an End, thine expectation shall not be cut off."
Proverbs 19:8 â "He that getteth wisdom, loveth his own Soul: he that keepeth understanding shall find good."
Proverbs 17:16 â "Wherefore is there a price in the hand of a Fool to get wisdom, seeing he hath no heart to it."

Philippians 3:13-14 â "Brethren, I count not my self to have apprehended: but this one think I do, forgetting those things which are behind, reaching forth unto those things which are before, I press toward the mark for the prize of the high calling of God in Christ Jesus."
2 Peter 3:14 â "Wherefore, beloved, seeing that ye look for such things, be diligent that ye may be found of him in peace, without spot, blameless."
2 Peter 1:14 â "Knowing that shortly I must put off this my Tabernacle even as our Lord Jesus Christ hat shewed me."

1 Peter 4:3-4 â "For the time past of our lives may suffice us to have wrought the will of the gentiles, when we walked in lasciviousness, lusts, excess of wine, revellings, banquetings, abominable idolatriesâ¦"
Supplement â it is unclear which sermon this was supplemental to.

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume is a record of the guest preachers at both Second Parish Rowley and Byfield, and the scriptures on which they preached. It also includes a section of vital statistics for Second Parish from ca. 1706 to ca. 1812.

did.unittitle: Sermons preached by Rev. Isaac Braman at Georgetown

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These sermons were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains manuscript sermons written and preached by Rev. Isaac Braman.

list.head: List of Sermons
list.item: John 4:24 â "God is a Spirit, they that worship him must worship in Spirit in truth."
Psalms 26:8 â "Lord, I have loved the habitation of thy house, and the place where thine honor dwelleth."
Hebrews 11:4 â "By faith Abel offered to God a more excellent sacrifice than Cain."
Zechariah 4:7 â "Who art thou, O great mountain? Before Zerubbabel thou shalt become a plain, he shall bring forth the headstone thereof with shouting, crying, Grace, grace unto it."
Job 19:21 â "Have pity upon me, have pity upon me, O ye my friends, for the hand of God hath touched me."

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This brief volume contains a list of marriages performed by Rev. Isaac Braman during his tenure. Most were performed at the church in Georgetown, and one or both participants were members there. Braman also recorded the fees he was paid for each ceremony, usually two or three dollars.

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: These church records were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The treasurers' ledger records the income and expenses of the parish, including taxes collected by assessors, staff salaries, fees for various services to the church, and the purchase of supplies such as firewood.

did.unittitle: Funeral sermon for Amos Spofford and Abigail Palmer

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: This sermon was digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions are available to view online.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "A sermon delivered at Rowley by the Rev. Isaac Braman, Dec. 29th 1805, occasioned by the death of Dr. Amos Spofford and Miss Abigail Palmer" on 2 Samuel 11:26 and Matthew 9:18. Spofford was a local physician and farmer, as well as one of the original members of the Massachusetts Medical Society. Abigail was the 14-year-old daughter of John and Martha Palmer.
